data.title: Peet's Coffee Founder Dies
data.meta_description: Alfred Peet, considered by many the "grandfather of specialty coffee," died last week at age 87. He started his own coffee business, Peet's Coffee, in Berkeley, Calif., in 1966. Peet mentored many gourmet coffee brewers since then, including the founders of Starbucks. The author of Uncommon Grounds: The History of Coffee and How It Transformed Our World offers a remembrance.
data.text:
ROBERT SMITH, host:

Back now with DAY TO DAY.

Madeleine, raise your coffee cup. And let's observe a moment of silence.

(Soundbite of slurping)

SMITH: That slurp goes out to the man who created gourmet coffee culture in the United States.

MADELEINE BRAND, host:

The Alice Waters of the bean, Alfred Peet.

SMITH: Alfred Peet.

(Soundbite of slurping)

BRAND: Mmm. That is good coffee. In 1966, Peet started a small coffee company in Berkeley, California. Peet's Coffee eventually grew into 150 stores in 10 states. And Peet's inspired the creators of Starbucks.

SMITH: Last week, Alfred Peet died at the age of 87.

Coffee expert Mark Pendergrast remembers the man.

(Soundbite of song, "Java Jive")

PUPPINI SISTERS (Group): (Singing) I love coffee, I love tea, I love...

Mr. MARK PENDERGRAST (Author, "Uncommon Grounds: The History of Coffee and How It Transformed Our World"): Peet told me the beans talk to you. You have to listen to them. The way that you roast each bean has to be individually tailored. You know, he just treated it as an artform that demanded respect. He said people who are used to drinking 10 cups of Hills Brothers Coffee, once they began to understand what really good coffee was about, they came back for the beans and to learn how to brew it properly from him.

Only a few came to sit at his feet to learn how to roast, but they became the vanguard of the new coffee industry. Now more and more people understand coffee can be almost a hallucinatory experience if you have the right beans from the right place. And I think that's a direct legacy of Alfred Peet.

SMITH: Alfred Peet, the founder of Peet's Coffee, died last week. He was 87.
